turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We’ll hear arguments next in 71-1043, Heller against New York.
Mr. Anolik, you may proceed whenever you’re ready.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
This case is somewhat similar to the prior case.
However, there are marked differences.

In this case, Your Honors, just to orient the Court briefly, on July 29, 1969, Inspector Smyth went to the Gerak Theater in Greenwich Village and saw a movie, which is the subject of the litigation before this Court, Blue Moon and apparently felt that it was obscene.

He then communicated with the Prosecutor’s Office and on July 31, 1969, together with Just-- the Judge Arthur Goldberg, no relation to any judge in this Court, he returned to the theater and Judge Goldberg and Inspector Smyth saw the film again.

At that point, after the film was completed at July 31, Judge Goldberg forthwith signed a search and seizure order without a hearing of any sort whatsoever and also issued warrants for the arrests of Mr. Heller, the petitioner here, and two other employees of the theater.

As it turned out, of course, two of the three arrests should never have occurred because, before the beginning of trial my concession with the District Attorney, those two arrests were-- those two individuals were dismissed in the case because they should never have been arrested.
The issue as to whether or not they should’ve been an adversary hearing is preserved in this record.

It is the position of the petitioner that in a First Amendment situation that we have here, the general rule appertaining to search and seizures cannot be followed, that an adversary hearing is essential to protect vital First and Fourteenth Amendment rights.
We have the seizure of a film.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I see.
You mean, an adversary hearing to determine obscenity del not.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That’s right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Not just probable cause.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, to determine obscenity del not.
That’s correct because, first of all, we do not have a clear and pleasant danger here as we might if a person possessed munitions or narcotics or something of that sort.

Indeed, we know from various cases and even from the history of this case before the New York Courts that there was sharp disagreement as to whether this film was even obscene and we do not, unlike our prior-- unlike the prior case, we do not for a moment concede that this was obscene.
In fact, we don’t think it was and, indeed, in the intermediate Appellate Court, the Appellate term of the Supreme Court.
The decision was two-to-one with Justice Markowitz dissenting and, in the New York Court of Appeals, the Chief Judge and another judge dissented and held that-- or said that the film was not obscene.
So, we have a real sharp issue as to obscenity, but I want to pass what I consider to be an even more paramount issue.
The problem that we face here is that once this film was seized and the printed--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Was it the only print?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes, the only print and, indeed, that--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that clear too in the record?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, it does not.
It does not appear clearly in the record.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Then how will we assume it?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, I can only say you asked a question and it has been told to me.

The District Attorney has taken the liberty toward the end of his brief to go outside the record to tell you what his experience has been with respect to subpoenas, and I ask this Court to accept it or reject it however--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Like the picture in the previous cases, it’s also showing in Washington?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I really don’t know.[Attempt to laughter]
However, let us assume, Justice Brennan, that arguendo it is the only print because if-- I don’t want to go--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You don’t think that makes a difference?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: It makes a difference? No, I don’t think it makes a difference at all.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the only print, what, in existence?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Apparently, the only one in existence.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Isn’t-- shouldn’t there be another question of whether there’s more than one print that might be available to this man?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: The-- apparently, there was no other available to this man, but we have an overwriting problem.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that clear in the-- is that clear in the record?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: It is not clear in the record, no.
It is not clear.
I’m asking the Court to assume arguendo, however, but that was a--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But you appreciate why we’re asking all those questions to call in both Quantity of Books and Marcus.
End--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I know.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The end result there was to take everything out right of the circulation.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I know that.
However, we maintain that the seizure of a film must be equated with the seizure of a mass Quantity of Books.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why, if there’s another film available?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Let us assume there’s another film available, Justice White, the deterrent effect of an immediate arrest for showing that other film casts a chilling effect and an impossible burden.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Marcus and Quantity didn’t hold that the man couldn’t be arrested right then.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I realize that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That issue has been on many times.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I realize that, but by the same token--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why is there any more of a chilling effect when in connection with movies?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, because of the fact that movies can be shown to a large audience.
In other words, it is the size of the audience that must be the criterion and not the item.

The District Attorney, indeed, in his brief says, on page 35, that this Court should consider the seizure of a film and equate it to a seizure of one book, and we do not subscribe to that and, indeed, the United--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I guess you wouldn’t even have to argue it if we-- the record show that, actually, this was the only print in existence, wouldn’t you?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Unfortunately, that was never actually developed in the record.
I have not tried the case.
It was not actually developed in the record, Justice Brennan.

But, to say that another print of the film is available, I think, actually begs the issue here because it is the adversary proceeding that we are addressing ourselves to at this time, and we think that is a very important issue and we are leading aside to the time being whether or not it’s even obscene.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, if this were, in fact, the only copy of this film in existence that it would not be such a unique composition that it would’ve been made the subject of some inquiry at the trial?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Perhaps it would, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are there very many films of which there is only one copy in this area?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, I would say that it’s quite unusual for a film to be produced where there’s only one print.
That’s quite unusual.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is this the kind of film that’s--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: This is a low-budget--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I mean, does it run the ordinary booking procedures?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: As far as I know, it was shown in only one theater in New York.
This was not syndicated through a number of theaters.
It was only at the Gerak Theater that this was being shown.
Apparently, it was a low-budget picture.
The quality of the film is not even good.
I think that’s conceded in the record.
It was--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is this as war hole?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: It’s a war hole film, but it’s not like some of those others which are being syndicated around town such as Heat and things of that sort.
This is a different type and this was apparently issued through a corporation of which he was one of the owners of the stock.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: There wouldn’t be much profit in it if there were only copy, would there?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: There probably would not be, but let us--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: There had to be.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: There may have been copies in the west coast.
That’s a possibility but, nonetheless, the seizure here amounted to what we consider to be a violation of the First Amendment.
Now, the problem that arises, of course, is that the film itself is seized and it’s true that the District Attorney argues that, well, a motion to suppress can be promptly made.

But, he casts the burden upon the defendant to make such a motion and says that were the burden otherwise, in other words, if an adversary hearing had to be held before you could seize a film, then a defendant could delay such an adversary hearing and delay justice, but you can turn that right around.
The District Attorney asks this Court to assume that the District Attorney or other prosecutor would never delay such a proceeding.
That is not at all evident.
We’re not dealing with New York County alone.
We’re dealing with an overwriting consideration here.

There could be delay on the part of a prosecutor but, more important than that, when we deal with a First Amendment situation such as this where we have a theater with 299 seats, and this incidentally is a closed theater.
This is not a theater such as in a Rave or in the Roaden case where maybe you can see something from the road.

Mr. Heller who testified, who happens to be an attorney incidentally, testified that the-- there was a sign in the lobby of the theater that the film was marked X, that no one under 17 would be admitted and, indeed, he said they, including him, enforced a rule that no one apparently under 18 was admitted.
There was no complaint received by any member of the public.

This was a situation where the police, apparently protecting some unknown and anonymous person, were arrogating to themselves the right of censorship over films, decided to look at the films and “well, we’re going to seize this film.”

That’s about the size of it, and we maintain that the problem of not holding the adversary hearing, in essence, means that the prosecutor can arrogate to himself the right to seize the film and to put the theater out of business because most theaters book films, let’s say, for three, four days a week or so.
It’s not that easy once the film is seized suddenly, as was-- as happened here, to suddenly get another replacement film.
It’s quite difficult in fact.
The arrest of the personnel is quite a traumatic effect, as indeed two of the three arrests here should not even have occurred.
And, the net result is that not only do you have an economic loss to the owner of the film, but you have a tremendous economic loss to the movie house, the exhibit.
Now, let us consider the situation where a prosecutor, perhaps not as liberal as some, decides that a particular movie is offensive.

That prosecutor, if he follows the procedure here, can handpick a judge and, incidentally, there’s no-- nothing in the record here one way or the other as to how Judge Goldberg was chosen to come down to Court.
So, we could-- we have a right at least to speculate that maybe this judge was handpicked, brought down, and he issues this forthwith warrant.

Now, if Judge Markowitz, for example, who dissented in the Appellant term, had been used as the magistrate, there would not have been a seizure, there would not have been an arrest and, indeed, this case may not-- might not have even been up here.

So, w have that dangerous situation in a First Amendment case whereby the District Attorney can decide, perhaps subject to a certain ethics of course, and we don’t maintain that all prosecutors necessarily have the ethics of the New York County District Attorney’s Office, but the fact remains that the magistrate came down there and forthwith issued this search and seizure order and arrest order.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do you know whether that’s a standard procedure?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Now, I understand that since this situation has occurred and in view of Death View Amusement Park, in the Second Circuit-- an astro film is in the Second Circuit and, indeed, decisions in Sixth Circuit Courts of Appeal-- I believe the procedure in New York County is that they do give out that sort of hearings now.
Apparently, it recognizes the serious question as to whether they should or should not.
This is the case which apparently will crystallize whether or not they should continue doing it, but I’m sure Mr. Friedman will be able to speak more authority as what the actual procedure is.

But, be that as it may, in the brief of the District Attorney, he says that Judge Goldberg and Inspector Smyth did not see or do not recall seeing signs that this was restricted to people over 17 years of age and that the film was marked X.
Mr. Heller testified under oath that that was in fact the case, and there’s nothing to contradict that in the record.
Merely, the fact they didn’t recall seeing it certainly is not contradiction.
The--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is that testimony in the record of Judge Goldberg and Inspector Smyth or is that just in the brief?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, that’s in the record.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It’s in the record.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Judge Goldberg testified and so did Inspector Smyth testify.

As a matter of fact, Justice Rehnquist, there was an attempt to cross-examine Judge Goldberg as to what criteria he used to determine what-- why this was obscene and, indeed, perhaps to determine if he was even familiar with the standards laid down by this Court in Roth and in other cases because I don’t think we have a right to assume that lower Court judges necessarily are always conversant with the standards laid down by this Court.

In an adversary hearing, at least these matters could be called to the attention of these jurors to determine “are you, in fact, judging this seizure by the standards set down by the Supreme Court of the United States or is it some visceral reaction that you are motivated by?”

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Your concept of an adversary hearing, that would be where the counsel for the defendant would have a right to cross-examine the magistrate?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: At least to cross-examine the complainant be he a magistrate or for Inspector Smyth.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I take it that Judge Goldberg here where it was not a complaint and he was basically in the position of someone who--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: He was the magistrate who issued the search warrant, that’s correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And you’re saying that in your concept of an adversary hearing defense counsel would have a right to cross-examine someone sitting in Judge Goldberg’s position?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No.
I would say that if the party at least who was in the role of the complainant.

The problem with this case, Justice Rehnquist, is that Judge Goldberg became a prosecution witness, so to speak, in this case saying that he determined that the film was obscene and, to that extent, having become a witness at the trial, counsel at least tried to determine what standards he had applied and they did not permit cross-examination as to that question.
I am not saying--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Excuse me.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes, Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Excuse me, I--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I am not saying that necessarily, in all cases, I would say that where a detached impartial magistrate issues a search warrant that you have a right to cross-examine him as to why he did it.
If I interpret it saying that, I didn’t mean to imply that, Justice Rehnquist.
I am saying that at least the complainant, in this case, Inspector Smyth.

At least to that extent, cross-examination should be permitted and an opportunity to call to the attention of the magistrate the precedence and the holdings of this Court and, perhaps, the Courts of New York as to what the definition of community standards are, what the definition of obscenity is under the Roth testing of the test.
That, at least, should have been permitted and ought to be permitted in any First Amendment situation case.
That is our position, Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is a copy of the search warrant in the appendix here?
I don’t seem to be able to find it.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I thought it was reproduced.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, perhaps it is.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Your friend from the state seems to indicate that he doesn’t think it’s in there.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What Judge Goldberg did find-- he didn’t find that this movie was obscene.
As a matter of fact, what did he recite?
There was probable cause to believe that--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: It-- if it were to follow the usual search warrant situation, it would say probable cause to believe that a search warrant should issue, and he applied a Fourth Amendment standard to a search and seizure situation.
That is what would obtain here, and that is the situation which, no doubt, motivated Justice Goldberg.
We maintain that a Fourth Amendment standard may not be applied in First Amendment situations such as this.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Anolik.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: When you talk about adversary hearing, what do you concede this to be?
I gather, certainly one element has to be and there has to be a judicial determination that the film is or is not obscene.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And, for that purpose, what kinds of proof would the city have to use and what kind of proofs and defense would you use?
Would this be a full-scale trial?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: It would certainly be a full-scale hearing.
They presumably have to--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: A full-scale trial?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: When you’re talking about a determination going on.
I suppose, nothing short of that--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That’s correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Would suffice, would it?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I would say not.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what does that mean?
That you could introduce all kinds of expert testimony?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Bearing on-- the city would have to prove obscenity.
Is this a city or a--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: This is the State of New York, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: State?
And, the state would have to--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: The County of New York.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The state would have the burden of proving obscenity in the first instance.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That’s correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And by what, preponderance or--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, I would say that they would have to prove it by the standard appertainable to a criminal prosecution.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Beyond reasonable doubt?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That’s right, beyond reasonable doubt.
I don’t think preponderance--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You mean, not because the object of seizing the film is to get evidence to support a criminal prosecution?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, the object of seizing the film here is to, in effect, take the film away, out of the possession of the individual and, while it’s true that is evidence, we maintain they must proceed by subpoena and, of course, with the subpoena you can make a motion to quash a subpoena.
But, in a First Amendment situation, we would ask that nothing less than a full adversary hearing--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I understand that.
I’m interested why you suggest it has to be beyond a reasonable doubt.
Is it that it’s connected with a possible criminal prosecution or even if it isn’t, you’d still say that it had to be unreasonable?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No.
If it’s an injunction, then I would say a fair preponderance of the credible evidence might be sufficient.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What you’re saying is that there must be a full-scale adversary criminal trial to determine whether there should be a full-scale adversary criminal trial.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I would say that the standard that you would use--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, isn’t that what you’re arguing?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: In effect, I would say-- although it seems to be rather logical to say that, I would say, in effect, that would have to be our position.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, there’s no escape from it, is there?
On your position, you want a trial to see whether there should be a trial.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, I would say that perhaps we could use a different standard because, as I understand it, a standard as to, for example, a fair preponderance might be sufficient to see that at least some gross miscarriage of justice has not occurred.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But then you’re backing away from your ammos to Justice Brennan.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I would be prepared, as I say, to at least reanalyze the standard of proof, in view of the way you set the question, Mr. Chief Justice.
I would be willing to do or at least concede--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, don’t let my questions mislead you.
I just want your answers.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, it is my position, as I say, that nothing less than a full adversary hearing where a proof beyond reasonable doubt is obtained should be had.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And yet, I take it, if the tryer applied beyond reasonable doubt standard and then they-- and determined obscenity and then a criminal prosecution ensued, you’d still insist the state had over again, in the criminal trial, to prove obscenity beyond a reasonable doubt.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, I would say that would, of course, would seem to be a situation where you’d have a jury trial perhaps on a different scale, because there you’d be trying--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But still, the st--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: An individual.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The standard for the decision of the jury would have to be obscenity beyond reasonable doubt.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes, but the point is, in the one case, you’re judging the film itself.
In the other case, you’re judging whether he promoted in-- obscenity.
It’s a little bit different standard there because it’s Section 235, the obscenity Section 235.05 that we have promoting obscenity.
So, it’s a little bit different standard that we’re dealing with.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Anolik.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Assuming that they follow this procedure and they seize the man who was showing the film who is the owner and he is also the operator, and you have this full adversary hearing and you lose there, and you have a second trial-- you have the trial and you waive the jury.
Please tell me the difference between the first hearing and the second.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: The first hearing would determine what the film itself--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I’m talking about what happens.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: What happens?
n the first hearing, there would be a determination of whether-- as to whether the film itself is obscene under appropriate community standards.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, in my case there’s no question the man showed it.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That he showed the film?
No, doubt about that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, in the second case, what other evidence would you put in?
The fact that he shown--
That he showed the film?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, he-- I think that we have--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What else would you put in?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, I think you’d have to show that he had knowledge and intent.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: To do what?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: To show an obscene film.
In other words, we maintain that there is, at the basis of a criminal statute, at least that degree of due process which would require the state to establish that this man knowingly and willfully--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The state shows that they went in the place and they found the man up in the place in the projection room running the camera and they also saw him picking up the money and there was nobody there but him.
Now, what else do you have to show?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, the-- I think you’d have to show some intent.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, that for example, this man, in good faith, believes this was not an obscene film because it’s--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, he’s already testified in the other hearing.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: He has testified, that’s right, but he was not the subject of the other hearing.
The subject of the other hearing was the film itself.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He wasn’t?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, we maintain that it was the film itself which is the criterion of the other hearing.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, suppose in this-- my hypothetical, they start this adversary hearing the day after the picture is shown, adversary hearing, and the other hypothetical is they start his trial on the merits the day after the hearing.
The difference being, what?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: The difference being that, in the one case--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I mean practical business.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: The practical is that, in the one case, we’re testing out whether or not the film itself should’ve been seized, whether or not it’s in fact obscene.
Let us assume the Court then decides that contrary to the position of the defendant, that they hold that the film was obscene.
The issue then is did he promote-- if he pleads not guilty, now, it may be that he was found in the projection room.
It may be that he was found taking money, but that would not automatically presume him guilty.
Having plead not guilty, he’d be entitled to a trial as to his own--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what we’re worried about, isn’t this just like some narcotics cases when you, as defense counsel, you lose the motion to suppress, you lose your case?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, I wouldn’t think so, because in narcotics cases there, again, has to be some element of criminal intent and knowledge because, frequently, a person who’s found in possession of heroin and there’s a chemical analysis.
There’s absolutely no doubt that the matter is heroin and that he was found with it and was sold to an agent.
That does not mean he’s not entitled to a trial in the merits.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I said I’m going to practical.
I said, practical.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: As a practical effect, I’ll say this.
That I have seen cases, Justice Marshall, where there had been disagreements or acquittals of defendants notwithstanding the fact that, on a motion to suppress, they lost the case they were called.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I wouldn’t push you a number.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: No, there aren’t too many of those.
I’d have to agree.

There aren’t too many of those because you are taking the narcotics here, but why don’t we take some other situation where we’re not dealing with anything as dramatic as narcotics, where we’re dealing with something, perhaps the possession of an unloaded gun or the possession, for example, of the material--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: All of those that I-- I limited mine to that because I don’t think the others apply.
I still-- I’m unconvinced of the difference between these two when you ins-- I only limited my questions that you insist that there’d be beyond reasonable doubt.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, as I said, I-- if you noted, I was willing to backtrack a little bit on that aspect.
I would say that I perhaps should adopt the standard of a fair preponderance for that purpose, and insist upon beyond reasonable doubt for the purpose of trial.

As I say, upon analysis, Justice Marshall, and if you would give me an opportunity perhaps to amend my rather adamant position previously, that perhaps upon reflection a preponderance test should be used in the initial hearing and reasonable doubt in the trial proper.
That would be perhaps a more reasonable situation.
What-- an adversary hearing, however, of some sort must, of necessity, be held, we maintain, to protect a First Amendment right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Anolik.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes, Justice Stewart?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How do you visualize this adversary hearing? The movie would have to be there, wouldn’t it?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: The movie would have to be there, but the point is this.
It should not be in-- with the possession of the District Attorney because assuming-- let’s say that we won the suppression hearing.
They said it should not have been seized.
Under New York law, the District Attorney could appeal that and retains possession of the property until it goes through the Appellate process.
He is not required to return that film because that’s true in all search and seizure cases.
The District Attorney can appeal forthwith if he says he cannot proceed with the case and, therefore, he retains possession of that until it goes through the full Appellate process.

We do not have a concomitant right of appeal if the suppression is not granted because we would have to either, plead guilty and then appeal, or else we have to go through a full trial and then appeal for the judgment of conviction before we could appeal that question.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that brings me back to my question.
How do you visualize that the final adversary hearing will work?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: It would work by--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Would there be a subpoena first to--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes, a subpoena and we maintain the subpoena is perfectly alright because there’s a contempt power behind it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: A subpoena duces tecum.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That’s correct, for the film.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: To the theater owner--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That’s right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: To produce the film and that immediately would take the film away--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Just--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: From the projection booth and deprive all these people of their First Amendment rights to see it.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: But just for one day, not for weeks or months or years, just for one day, just for the purpose of showing it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You’re suggesting that--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: And then it’s immediately returned.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You’re suggesting that the subpoena has to be-- that the hearing has to be within a matter of hours after the subpoena?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I’d say that they would have to schedule a showing.
On the subpoena, you are to bring the subpoena on the-- at 10 a.m. on Monday, whenever it might be, for the purpose of showing it to the Court.
They bring it there at that time, they show it to the Court, and they take it right back to the theater.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then, when you come to the later trial, how is the state going to meet its burden of proof of showing that the film brought in at the trial is the same film they had--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: But, that’s true--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: At the preliminary?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, Mr. Chief Justice, that’s true of any situation where you have subpoenaed records.
As I understand, a subpoena does not entitle--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You can make copies.
You can do a lot of things.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well-- but, it’s not that easy.
It has to be taken to particular labs.
Exhibitors don’t have the facilities to do that and, also, why should we imply bad faith on the part of any citizen without proof of that?
I mean, why is it that the District Attorney can do no wrong?
The District Attorney might doctor that film, for all we know, if he has it in his position.
Why should we assume that he wouldn’t do that?I mean, if this is custodia legis in the hands of an individual, it’s his property.
Why should he be deprived of it and why should we--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I suppose there could be ancillary restraints on its return against tampering with it and so forth, which would--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Which would subject the exhibitor to contempt if it--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Not only contempt, perhaps forgery prosecution of offering a forged document.
I mean, I think there are a lot of inhibitions that can be done.
Now, Sixth Circuit Courts of Appeal have held that adversary hearing should be held.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Just-- I wasn’t-- I’m not finished with my questions.
Your idea-- your submission is that there’d be a subpoena and that the constitution requires that the hearing be very, very prompt after--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That’s correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The theater owner shows up in response to this subpoena duces tecum.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And then, let’s assume that the magistrate, after the adversary hearing, finds that this probably is or that the prosecution has sustained its burden of proving by a preponderance of the evidence that this is obscene, and then what happens?
Does he--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: What happens is then, it’s true.
He’s going to be the problem of his film.
He’s going to be the problem of his film--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is he?
Wouldn’t you--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I thought that you would say that the constitution requires that, nonetheless, the film be returned to the theater until or unless there’s been a criminal conviction.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I’m sorry.
Did you say before the criminal conviction?
I misunderstood your question.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: We’re talking about this--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: The hearing--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Adversary hearing that you say the constitution requires.
I’m trying to find out what it is in your hard work.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: And if it’s only the adversary hearing, they would have to wait for a conviction on the merits, we would maintain.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So that--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Before that was done.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So that, although there’s a finding by the magistrate that the preponderance of the evidence shows that this is an obscene film.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Then, you say that, after such a finding, the constitution requires that the film be returned to the theater.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Your Honor, we would have to say, to take a constant position, that until there’s a finding of guilt by a Court that the film, it being a First Amendment property right we’re dealing with--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Should not be seized at all.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That’s what I thought.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: We don’t think that present situation requires that to be seized.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, you see, because all these cases in these briefs talk about an adversary hearing and I have a very great deal of trouble visualizing what--

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: It would be an adversary hearing and we--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What the counsel had in mind.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: We would use a standard of a fair preponderance.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Alright and--there’s a finding that by a fair preponderance of the evidence the film is obscene, then you say the constitution then requires the film to be returned to the theater?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That’s correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Immediately or very promptly.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: As promptly as possible.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And then the case comes to trial, then what happens?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Again, through subpoena, it is displayed to the Court, and until there’s a finding of guilty, it should not be seized.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it’s subpoenaed and then displayed to the finder of the fact, the jury or the trial judge.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That’s correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And then it’s-- and then, assuming it’s a criminal trial, then the man may be punished but the film never does gets seized, does it?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Well, eventually, if it’s deemed to be obscene after a trial on the merits beyond a reasonable doubt, then I presume they could seize it because it would technically be contraband at that point.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Anolik.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: Yes?

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Suppose it were feasible for a copy of the film to be reproduced promptly, say, by an independent lab. Under circumstances, it would assure that there was no tampering with the film and that your client, therefore, could have the original back in 24 hours.
Would that satisfy your First Amendment position?

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: I would say so.
I think for-- like a video tape or something of the films?

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That might be-- that would probably satisfy it.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: This would avoid having the duplicate trials.

turn.speaker: irving_anolik
turn.label: Mr. Irving Anolik
turn.text: That’s correct.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Friedman.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

The state has, as this Court has held many times, a valid important interest in the prosecution of obscenity and the enforcement of the obscenity laws and that is a state interest which may be vindicated in any number of ways.

The state has a number of alternatives opened to it, and the Court has also held that if there is an important governmental interest which might incidentally limit protected speech that the Court must weigh the interest of the state on one hand and the procedures used so that the incidental effects can be minimized and that it is this tight of balance that must be decided in any given situation.
And, what have we here?
We have here a situation where the state has chosen to use its penal statutes, its penal provisions which impose a penalty for the prior showing of the film.

That is, they do not aim at the future showing but only at the showing that occurred at some point in the past at some act the defendant has already performed and, in the course of enforcing this valid state interest of imposing a penalty for the past showing, the state of necessity must have evidence.
And, in order to obtain evidence, there are two choices at this stage.
The state, in a case of a film, must have testi-- can have testimony of someone who has seen the film that testifies to its contents, or can have the film.
Now, if a person who has seen the film tries to testify, the problems of proof are, in many cases, overwhelming.
And I believe, as the summary of evidence which we have given in our brief indicates, any testimony concerning Blue Movie would have been very hard to discern by the tryer of fact.
It is a type of movie which can be seen in its entirety, as it-- sorry, which must be seen in its entirety as the only way to ascertain what this movie is.
The description is very difficult to do and, I say, even counsel, with great deal of leisure, have had difficulty attempting to summarize it in any useful form.
Now, given this problem, why should the state be relegated to less than the best available probative evidence of a crime?
Why must the state rely on secondary evidence which is really, in a case of this sort, worthless?
Because, in this case, I would submit that a finder of fact would have had almost impossible task in figuring out what Blue Movie is about.

Now, they say the state has chosen the penal sanction, and I mention that because that distinguishes, in large part, many of the prior cases in this Court where states have tried a civil injunctive remedy.
That is where the state has attempted to prevent future showing.
What we are doing here is enforcing a right against past showings.
Now, it is true--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why do you need to take the film out of circulation?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Your Honor, we-- the film didn’t have to be withdrawn from circulation in order to prosecute it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You seized it, didn’t you?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: We did seize the film and, in partial answer of a question Mr. Justice Marshall had asked before, the film was currently in this Court’s custody actually.
It was delivered to the Court by the District Attorney.
We still have the film, but--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Was-- Wouldn’t it have been enough for your purposes to subpoena it for the trial?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the subpoena route is not as simple, I submit, as has been suggested by my adversary.
The subpoena route has raised many serious Fifth Amendment problems where the perspective defendant is subpoenaed to produce a document in his possession which is incriminating.
And, as a practical matter, we have been subjected to collateral proceedings every time we ever tried the subpoena route.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: At the time of the trial, the film would finish its showing and they’d be out of jurisdiction anyways.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s correct, and I think the contemptor’s power is not a very effective one for this reason. As has been mentioned several times here, the films are on a schedule of circulation and if the current distributor--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But if there were--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Has a contract right which limits his right to possession to a very limited period of time, he may well have a defense to any contempt proceeding.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Ordinarily, does he get more than one print?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: The individual distributer, generally, would have one print, although--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that the sort of distribution method this film was subject to?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I presume that each person who had this film had one print in his possession.
The record doesn’t tell us, but that more than one print exists, I think, is just facing the facts of--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know, but that--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Commercial distribution.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That doesn’t mean much if there’s not a second print available to this exhibitor, does it?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: We don’t know whether there’s a second print available to this exhibitor.
We don’t know what the terms of his distribution agreement were.
He never put any of this in the record, Your Honor.
If the-- if he was going to lie on that claim, then the record is--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let’s assume that there were two copies readily available to him and you could have one of them but he could go on showing the other.
If all you want is evidence, just having one copy but letting the other one show would satisfy your need, wouldn’t it?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, it certainly would, Your Honor.
There are a number of situations where films have shown in several theaters even within the city and we have seized one print for evidence, but the problem is this, and it’s a very practical problem.
The seizure of that first print will effectively tell any defendant who is represented by competent counsel that perhaps he ought not to show the film in the future.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: But not because we are preventing it, but because practicality of law enforcement is that the penal sanction, having been invoked as to one showing, the man runs a risk of subsequent prosecution.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, isn’t that--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Where they’re not subsequent seizure.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What’s the significance of that?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Well, the point is, Your Honor, that the mere fact that the film is not shown again even if he had a second print available would not necessarily be because the state would seize it, but because the man might be well-advised not to show it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but that’s a little different situation than when you effectively preclude him from showing the film.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Each exhibition is a new crime, is it not?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That’s correct, Your Honor.

I do not recall, offhand, the situation where we have actually prosecuted multiple counts for every repeated showing, but I can bring to this Court’s attention a case which is currently pending in the Courts of New York County in which we have started a prosecution and this prosecution was started by the same route as was used here, the issuance of a search warrant on August 17, 1972.
On August 18, the judge who awarded the seizure directed the film to be returned to the distributor.
That film was at the hand of the distributor.
It has never been produced in Court to this date.
It was on the calendar for yesterday.
It was not produced yesterday.
The distributor is showing it.
Since the time of the seizure, I believe published reports have shown that about $400,000 in gross has been taken-in in this picture.
It’s a film showing in several theaters in New York.
The prospect of the defendant being charged with multiple counts has maybe not dissuaded him, although the statute of limitations has not yet run in that case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why did they tell you that until you decide obscenity, you’re not supposed to take steps to preclude circulation of it?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: But, Your Honor, the problem is this, and that’s why I refer to this case involving a film called Deep Throat which, I believe, is referred to in one of the briefs for amicus curiae in this matter, a motion in brief which has not yet been accepted by the Court.
In that case, the defendant has no incentive in conducting a hearing.
There is no interest on this defendant’s part.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, isn’t there a solution?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: They have this case come to a hearing.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Isn’t there a solution to go to trial?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Our-- we have made every effort, Your Honor.

This matter has been on the calendar on six occasions by my count and, yet, we cannot force the case to a hearing, but why? Because the exhibitor who is commercially exploiting the film will not, in any way, cooperate with prosecution, and I think that some of the suggestions made by my adversary are perhaps suggestions of fantasy because there is not cooperation.
There is a reported case in the official reports which we cite in our brief in which an adversary hearing was attempted in New York County.
That was our last attempt.
That also went on for six weeks.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I thought Mr. Anolik suggested to us earlier that because of some decisions of the Second Circuit you are actually providing an adversary hearing.
Is that so?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Your Honor, we have been held.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: How many?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: To my recollection, there had been three.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What form did they take?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Well, the first one was in 1970.
It went on through the summer.
We served the defendant a notice of an adversary hearing to be held the next day.
The upshot of that--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What was this--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Six weeks later--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Before whom, a magistrate?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Before a magistrate.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Six weeks later, there were three days of testimony given by defense experts.
Two weeks after that, the judge handed down an opinion.
Six weeks after that, there was a motion for re-argument on the question of the prior adversary hearing.
Our experience in that case led us to litigate this case.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I understand you saying there’d been two other instances?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Are they different or are they the same?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: One terminated in an Article 78--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what kind of case--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: -- It would never go to a full hearing.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What time of case-- or what kind of case did the state put in, in this first case?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: The film.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Nothing but the film?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Nothing but the film.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And then rested?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: And then rested.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And then the defense put on expert testimony, is that it?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s correct.
In the third case, I refer to as Deep Throat which has not yet come to a hearing, we have tried.
Indeed, it is this problem that faces us in the Second Circuit which has-- which prompted our office to, in response to the certiorari petition, to suggest the Court hear this case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, if there’s a due process right as to--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Because there is a problem in New York--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Friedman, is there’s a due process right to some kind of a hearing, adversary or otherwise, do you suggest that that right can yield to the fact that some judges in New York don’t get on with the trial of their cases?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: No, Your Honor, our proposition is this.
That the state stands ready to give the man an adversary hearing immediately, forthwith, on the seizure.
At the time of the seizure, the man is brought before a magistrate.
If he wants a hearing, he can have a hearing because the state’s whole case is available.
That is, the film is before the Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it may--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I thought you have the hearing.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Because I--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The judge wanted to get to it and hold it, is that it?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Well, no, Your Honor.
I think Justice Harlan, in his dissent in Quantity of Books from market, 11 days was a reasonable time for a defendant to request to prepare a defense.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I guess, he’s entitled to some time.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: He’s entitled to time and the question of how much time.
He’s entitled to counsel, to declaration--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That’s for your state judges, isn’t it, not for the rest to decide?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Your Honor, if the First Amendment mandates an adversary hearing, then I submit that what we have is the Sixth Amendment mandating a delayed adversary hearing--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What about that procedure-- is it still obtained in New York when we have in king--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Kingsley Books.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Kingsley Books?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that’s now--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Didn’t that require a hearing within a day or something and a decision within two days?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That procedure was not applicable to films in the first instance.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I know, but is that still--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: It is now.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is it now?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: It has been amended to be applicable to films.
To my knowledge, no proceeding under that section has been--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: As I recall, that one-- doesn’t that-- that requires a hearing within what, one day or something?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, and as the cases of this Court have indicated, those hearings also go on for months, that, although the hearings are required, the defendants request time and, in Kingsley Books, they consented to the injunction pendently to provide time to prepare.
But, our experience with obscenity, defendants has not been that of--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, but I take it if they--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Of a consent to delay.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If they ask for more time and the Court grants it, that’s too bad to the state but that’s hitting it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The film-- isn’t the film-- aren’t films subject to a different approach, in any event, to licensing?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Not in New York.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In advance?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Not in New York currently.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know, but constitutionally it could be--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: I believe the Court has said yes, although I believe the current state of the law has been to-- they’ve been repealed in, I believe, every state though I won’t-- I’m not sure.
They had--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, certainly not under the--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: As a result of this Courts’ decisions which have cut down the proceeding--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but we never said in Freedman that there couldn’t be such a support.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: No, Your Honor, but in Freedman the Court said that a temporary removal of a film from exhibition for a limited period, pending rapid state proceedings, was permissible.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But, why isn’t that-- why doesn’t that still obtain?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Even in censorship cases.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: In a case of this type, and that’s what I see here, is that this man has shown the film in the past.
He has not been prevented in showing it in the first instance, as in the censorship case.
He has shown the film for several days.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but if any-- but if you think the other approach is preventing from showing in advance, then there is some pressure on him to get on with the hearing, and then the state starts dragging his feet.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s correct, Your Honor, except that in these instances, and that all we can speak of is the experience.

And, I think that the experience has indicated that the state is ready to cooperate and conduct a hearing, but to follow out the analogy on the censure case, in a censorship situation, a limited period of delay, however short the cases may differ, but a limited period is permissible.
That is all that the state is really seeking here.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is there some reason--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: And, prior to a judicial hearing--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is there some reason, Mr. Friedman, now that you’ve amended that Kingsberg-- was it Kings--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Kingsley Books.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Kingsley Books statute, is there any reason you don’t resort to that instead of this type of proceeding?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: The first answer, Your Honor, is that the statute-- the amendment, I believe, became effective in August of 1972.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that’s a good reason.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Secondly, it’s a-- I have been told that the effectiveness of the Kingsley Books statute is somewhat limited because it’s a-- in a book situation.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It’s an injunction proceeding.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: It had been a very cumbersome procedure to serve and hold in advance.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It’s an injunction procedure, isn’t it?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: It’s a purely civil injunction procedure which is now contained in the Civil Practice Act.
It’s not in civil practice law of the rules.
It’s no longer part of the criminal procedure statutes in New York, but in a situation here, we are only asking of a seizure for a limited period, a very limited period, until it can be a hearing.

We want a speedy hearing because there is no reason for these cases to remain in the Court structure at all if the def-- if the film is seized inadvertently, and really that’s what we’re talking about.
We’re really just talking about the possible effect on the First Amendment if a film is improperly seized in the first instance.
Those films should be returned to circulation forthwith, but if a film is properly seized, after hearing, a state may hold it.
I mean, even under a Quantity of Books after a full adversary hearing or, say in case of this sort, after a trial, the state may validly maintain custody of the film.
Indeed, an injunction could issue after the trial.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I take it on the ground that if there’s a determination of obscenity that takes it outside the First Amendment.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Therefore, it could be treated as without or--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Contraband or--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, whether it’s contraband, in any event--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Or a nuisance or one, whatever the appropriate rupert might be under the particular jurisdiction but, the point is, here--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there anything that prevents you from going down at the District Attorney from going from judge to judge, through about 30 judges until he finds one that agrees with him?
Is there anything to stop that?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Your Honor, there is nothing to stop, but there is nothing to stop it in any search warrant case.
In any case in which a Court has multiple judges who have concurrent jurisdiction, there is nothing to prevent judge-shopping for the purposes of trial.
Somehow or rather, a judge must be selected.

Now, as a practical matter, the only thing I understand New York law would require is that if there were multiple applications for a search warrant, you must indicate to the magistrate you apply to the history of the prior applications.
It is-- the magistrate must know that you’ve gone to someone before.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: But the real problem is getting a magistrate willing to hear it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you justified this on the fact that, I think I heard you correctly, that if it’s found out that it was obscene then that makes everything alright.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: I wouldn’t justify judge-shopping.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, but I mean--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Except as a--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But, I thought you shared-- what prompted my question was that once the hearing does determine that the picture is obscene, however it was seized and under whatever conditions, it’s nothing at all.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Well, to the extent that--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Which is not my idea of search and seizure.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: No, the questions is what’s before the magistrate on a question of search and seizure and, in New York, that magistrate has seen the film--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, the fact--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Which is the whole-- all the evidence that there really is, from the prosecution’s point of view, what the--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: For a minute, on search and seizure, if you make an illegal search and you find a million pounds of the purest of heroin in the world.
The fact that it’s pure heroin doesn’t protect it, does it?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Not at all, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Isn’t that-- do you want to make that true here too?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Your Honor, we’re not trying to vindicate a search by what--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you’re vindicating the seizure of property which allegedly is under First Amendment protection.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Allegedly.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Allegedly, Your Honor, but what we have in this case, and I think you’ve realistically thrown all of these cases, we have had a search and seizure where a magistrate has seen the evidence and has found eh film to be obscene.
Now, there’s some question as to what you found and I just would quote from the judge who issued the warrant, and this appears in the record.
“I had seen the film and it was and is my opinion that that film is obscene and was obscene as I saw it then under the definition of obscene, Section 235.00, the Penal law.”
Now, the judge--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That’s obscene under the state law of New York.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
