turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Under the state law of New York, Your Honor, and I think as we set forth the state statute at the outset of our brief, I think the Court will see that that is as close a paraphrase as the legislative draftsman was capable of doing of the three-fold test this Court has announced in its five decisions on obscenity.
If the state statute is--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: My sound instead to give a proof of what you’re in.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I think that that question is one which can be seen from the statute itself, that the state has codified the sound in this question--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why can’t we have this hearing, other than the fact that it takes time?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Why not hold the hearing, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, other than the fact that it takes time.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: After a magistrate has seen the film, we run a substantial risk, and has been mentioned several times today, of alteration of a film, we run the risk of film disappearing because of will, and these are not imaginary.
I think there is some concrete examples referred to in our brief where it has occurred, and the remedies of contempt are not practical.
If the film itself is gone and the original version is not available for comparison, the hearing process itself will have to be held sooner or later.
The state--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, why go through any hearing?
Why don’t you just go and seize it?
They did go through the trouble of getting the magistrate.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, if all you say is true, why’d you worry about getting the magistrate?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Your Honor, because the Fourth Amendment requires that there’d be a neutral and detached magistrate who ascertains that there is grounds for seizure and this Court has suggested in Marcus that the First Amendment does run into that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And then you can--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: We might suggest that the magistrate must have, as close to firsthand, knowledge of the material to be seized as is possible in order for him, in his judicial role, to make that decision.
That’s why the magistrate is required in this seizure as in any other.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And this man has been without this film for how long now?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: This stage, three years.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Huh?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Three years and four months to this date.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And that doesn’t give any problem?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Your Honor, there has been a final adjudication beyond a reasonable doubt that this film was obscene and, given that final adjudication and in 48 days after the seizure, the state may validly seize and hold that film.
It is not protected once--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Forever?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Forever?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: I would see no reason why not.
The--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would that apply to a book?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: The single copy of the book that is seized, certainly.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It would apply to a book?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Your Honor--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Even if it was the only book?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: If it’s the only book--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If it was the only copy?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s correct, Your Honor, and--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It could be seized--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: A final adjudication of obscenity has been made.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then it could be kept forever?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Or, as a matter of fact, destroyed?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s probably true, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And that gives you no First Amendment problems?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: No, Your Honor, as long as the state has a--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you mind if it gives me some?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s why we’re here, Your Honor.

That is-- the problem is that the Court has held that the First Amendment does not protect obscenity and, at some stage, a decision must be made in one form or another whether a matter is obscene or isn’t.
And, in this situation, we have a finding beyond a reasonable doubt by, in this case, a non-jury trial, three-judge trial, and that is a final judicial determination of the obscenity of this film.
Now, of course, it’s subject to review on appeal and were the film, returned or destroyed, as a practical matter, the Court would be unable to review it.
And, it is for that reason the film is, as I say, in the custody of the Court Clerk’s Office at the current time, but once that determination is made--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We wouldn’t have that problem in the case we had earlier because somebody destroyed it.
We could just go down the street here in Washington and see it.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: If it’s the same film, Your Honor, and I believe the Attorney General from Kentucky indicated he hadn’t seen it to see if it is the same film.
And, I would submit that if the Court choose to see Blue Movie-- you’d see that it’d be very difficult to ascertain if this was the same film.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Does the New York statute have any provision for destruction of material when finally adjudicated obscene?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Not that I am aware of, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Other than-- I mean-- Even after-- I’m just interested.

After the adjudication, and what’s the basis upon which-- of course, it may be treated, as we agreed without, as now, no longer entitled to any First Amendment consideration at all when finally adjudicated, but how does that still entitle you to keep it?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, to return it at any stage creates as--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I think, usually--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Many problems as the retention.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, usually, these statutes provide for its destruction in that situation.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: MIt may be a statute in New York, Your Honor, that I’m unaware of.
I just indicate that, to my knowledge, there is none and, as a practical matter in a case which has been reported--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I mean, when it’s--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: If the film is gone, the precedential value of the cases--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: When it’s heroin or something like that, isn’t there some statutory provision in which you keep it?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Not-- the statutes are vague, at best, as to the right to retain or destroy evidence at the expiration of a case.
As a general matter, heroin is fungible and not necessarily valuable after a case is disposed of.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But it’s contraband, isn’t it?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: It certainly is, and it’s generally destroyed, but--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You don’t return it to the defendant.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: We certainly don’t return heroin to defendants.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But you do destroy it, you don’t know whether that’s done under statutory authority or just--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: I presume there is a statute regulating the police property clerk which governs that but, as a practical matter, I think the Court’s aware there’s a substantial problem in obscenity cases of the Bar or anyone else knowing precisely what the item that has been adjudicated is, and that the objects are usually retained for as long as it is possible to keep them in some form of intact state or another so as to provide that insight for further study, so that in most cases and certainly in most obscenity cases the material that’s been seized has been held for years and years.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Isn’t it some place in Brooklyn that has this “library” on it?
Is it the federal or the state?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: I believe the State of New York was in the process of setting one up.
I don’t know if they actually did.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, I thought so.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: The value of a library of obscenity--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I think you need to use the word “library.”[Laughter]

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Well, I think that’s the way it’s been popularly described, Your Honor.

But, the point we face here is that the state’s effort that New York has adopted of acquiring the magistrate to actually see the material is one which walks, we think, a fair middle ground between the seizure by an untrained officer who sees a film and then seizes it and a procedure where perhaps, if the state is lucky, a hearing can be held prior to the time the film is removed from the jurisdiction.
And, the adversary hearing approach in the limited cases in which we have tried it has been very unsuccessful, and I don’t blame the judges of New York for this purpose.
It is, in fact, the nature of the obscenity business which puts the incentive of delay and obstruction on the defendant.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But who’s in charge of the calendar in New York, judges or the--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Your Honor, it is the judges, but the defendant’s Fifth-- Sixth Amendment right to counsel is generally what has been interjected and, I think, not unjustifiably where counsel needs time to prepare.
It certainly needs time to prepare.
He has to see the film.H
e has to come get experts.
Experts have to be contacted.
They have to see the film.
A lengthy period of time is required.

We cannot have-- if a full-pledged hearing, as Mr. Anolik suggested, be held, if that is what an adversary hearing is and, Mr. Justice Stewart, I don’t think anyone is really to find what it is because the Court is just simply saying either one is needed or isn’t and leave it to the states to work out what they will.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So, you--

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: But if a hearing is required, then the problem of delay is forced into the hearing process by the Sixth Amendment, if nothing else.
It’s not even bad faith.
It may even be good faith, but there must be delay.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you-- if it were the other way, then the state concedes and holds pending what you say is necessarily a period of time for preparation?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: If the def-- if the person who had custody of the film requires a time for preparation, then the state-- if he wants the time, then should that state return it to him during that period.
I mean, that’s the practical effect of the question because we are ready for a hearing once the film has been seized as before the Court.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I suppose you might say too that, although frequently defense counsel in criminal cases will want delay in the actual trial of the action, they may not insist on delay of-- for preliminary hearing.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: No, they may or they may not, depending on how it suits the strategy of a particular defense, but the question is whether the state must be put in a position where delay is a matter of right, and I think that the Sixth Amendment would make it a matter of right.
So that, it is particularly appropriate in this instance where, in a movie case, the state’s only proof is the film.

More than the film would not be required and submitted, and that can be held at the movie theater when the man is arraigned promptly, we have Courts operating from 9 in the morning until midnight every day.
Hearings can be held, but who should have the burden of initiating it after a judge has seen the film and has made a determination?
Because, we submit, that it is the judicial presence and not the adversary’s presence which is the crux of what this Court has tried to say in Marcus and A Quantity of Books.
That is, there must be a magistrate who’s made a specific determination on a specific film and how as to whether he must hear argument or not, we can’t tell.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I suppose the word “adversary” has appeared first in Marcus.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That ordinarily connotes, doesn’t it, a contest?

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, but the problem of how much of a contest.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I know.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: The New York Court of Appeals, in this case, in its opinion seem to treat it as being a question of argument as oppose to a question of proof.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But what you’re doing now with the magistrate going to the theater, that-- there’s no-- nothing in the way of a contest.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s correct, Your Honor, but it does bring the--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And to that extent, if the principle of Marcus and Quantity of Books applies in this situation, to that extent, surely your procedure is deficient.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: If it is a full contest at that stage which is required.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But, here, there’s no contest at all.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: That’s correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Whatever the contest may be, I just suggest that I think Marcus and Quantity of Books does suggest there has to be some contest.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the sug-- the reading the New York Courts have taken I think is a reasonable one and that is that the constitution in the seizure of possibly protected material requires more than an officer’s statement as to probable cause, and if a magistrate, bringing the judicial mind to the question of obscenity, has made a determination which, for all intense and purposes, must be a prima facie determination, not one of probably cause.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And an ex parte one.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: It may be ex parte in that--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that’s what it is.

turn.speaker: lewis_r_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Lewis R. Friedman
turn.text: It may be ex parte, but that doesn’t necessarily make it deficient because in a judge-- in deciding the questions of obscenity, there are no questions of fact in the sense of an informant type of search warrant case.
It’s not a factual determination.
It’s an inference determination, an inference from basically a conceded fact, that is, the film is conceded to be here.
From that film, what inference could be drawn?

And, to require the defendant’s presence with counsel and, conceivably, experts and we really don’t know what else, at this stage, would really be an unreasonable burden of a valid state interest, a valid state interest which this Court has upheld in saying that the prosecution of obscenity laws may be continued.
So that, we submit that the New York practice under which a magistrate seize a film prior to the issuance of a warrant of allegedly obscene material is constitutionally sufficient.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
